<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™

CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/41  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 299, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 300, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 213, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A skydiver of mass \(76\mathrm{kg}\) is falling vertically in still air. At time \(t = 0\), the skydiver opens his parachute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 608, 133]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 is the speed–time graph for the skydiver from \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 141, 843, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 534, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 421, 146, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 373, 440]]<|/det|>
Using Fig. 1.1, determine:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 180, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 450, 776, 468]]<|/det|>
the deceleration of the skydiver immediately after the parachute opens

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 524, 920, 544]]<|/det|>
<form>deceleration = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 554, 180, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 554, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
the force due to air resistance acting on the skydiver immediately after the parachute opens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 644, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ............................................................ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 674, 148, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 673, 910, 692]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of the forces acting on the skydiver, his motion between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 6.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 816, 144, 835]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 816, 850, 834]]<|/det|>
Explain why opening the parachute cannot reduce the speed of the skydiver to zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 915, 920, 933]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 931, 920, 948]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 833, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows a wooden trolley of mass \(1.2\mathrm{kg}\) at rest on the rough surface of a bench.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 98, 813, 183]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 197, 532, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
A ball of mass \(0.52 \text{g}\) travels horizontally towards the trolley. The ball embeds itself in the wood of the trolley. The trolley moves with an initial speed of \(0.065 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 274, 146, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 243, 292]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 180, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 305, 472, 323]]<|/det|>
the impulse exerted on the trolley

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>impulse = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 428, 180, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 428, 527, 447]]<|/det|>
the speed of the ball as it hits the trolley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 522, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 146, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 747, 571]]<|/det|>
As the trolley moves across the rough surface, it slows down and stops.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 920, 617]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of the work done, the energy change that takes place as the trolley slows down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 753, 920, 771]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 752, 91]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 717, 214]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows a device that uses liquid pressure to lift heavy boxes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 222, 863, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 549, 532, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 586, 599]]<|/det|>
The boxes are lifted by pumping oil into the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 920, 645]]<|/det|>
The force upwards on the piston due to the oil, and the force downwards on the piston due to the air above the piston, combine to produce a constant force of \(8800 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 658, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the air is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\) and the cross-sectional area of the bottom surface of the piston is \(0.016 \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 705, 180, 723]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 704, 747, 723]]<|/det|>
Calculate the pressure of the oil at the bottom surface of the piston.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 812, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<form>pressure = ....................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 633, 89]]<|/det|>
As the boxes are lifted, the depth of the oil increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Explain why the pump must exert an increasing pressure on the oil as the depth of the oil increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 208, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 240, 180, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 240, 897, 259]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why the force of \(8800 \text{N}\) in (b) cannot lift boxes of weight \(8800 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 333, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 658, 89]]<|/det|>
An aluminium saucepan with a plastic handle contains cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 475, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the saucepan on a hotplate.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 153, 828, 304]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 319, 533, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 146, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 808, 368]]<|/det|>
State why the pan is made from aluminium but the handle is made from plastic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 146, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
The hotplate is switched on and, as the temperature of the water increases, the internal energy of the water increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 181, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 831, 508]]<|/det|>
State, in terms of molecules, what is meant by an increase in internal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 583, 180, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 583, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of the atomic lattice and electrons, how thermal energy is transferred through the aluminium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 720, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 752, 181, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 752, 920, 785]]<|/det|>
Eventually, the water reaches boiling point. Thermal energy from the hotplate is still being transferred to the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 800, 824, 817]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of molecules, the effect of this thermal energy on the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 923, 920, 940]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The mass of the water decreases by \(0.11 \text{kg}\) in \(300 \text{s}\). The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water is \(2.3 \times 10^6 \text{J/kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 680, 135]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rate at which the water gains thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 241, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<form>rate of gain of energy = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 273, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 618, 91]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.1 shows the structure of a liquid-in-glass thermometer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 109, 819, 203]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 920, 265]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 277, 146, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 276, 705, 295]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 400, 143, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 851, 419]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 523, 141, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 523, 920, 558]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 305]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 412, 920, 429]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student sets up a circuit that includes a \(12\mathrm{V}\) battery, an \(800\Omega\) resistor, a voltmeter and a thermistor. Fig. 8.1 is an incomplete circuit diagram because the symbol for the thermistor is missing.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 127, 672, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 307, 532, 325]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 584, 357]]<|/det|>
The thermistor is connected between terminals P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 144, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 860, 388]]<|/det|>

The \(12\mathrm{V}\) battery consists of eight identical cells connected in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 598, 450]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[517, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<form>e.m.f. = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
There are three naturally occurring isotopes of hydrogen: hydrogen-1, hydrogen-2 and hydrogen-3. The nuclide notation for hydrogen-1 is \(^1_1\mathrm{H}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 574, 140]]<|/det|>
Write down the symbol, using nuclide notation, for:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 168, 443, 186]]<|/det|>
hydrogen-2 ................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 443, 233]]<|/det|>
hydrogen-3. ................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 230, 920, 249]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 260, 146, 279]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 260, 890, 279]]<|/det|>
In a fusion reactor, a nucleus of hydrogen-2 and a nucleus of hydrogen-3 undergo fusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 291, 180, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 291, 510, 310]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 414, 180, 433]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 414, 747, 433]]<|/det|>
The fusion reaction produces a free neutron and one other particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 446, 831, 465]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 920, 620]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 632, 764, 651]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 662, 175, 681]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 693, 175, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
